name: GNU Astronomy Utilities (Gnuastro)
description: The GNU Astronomy Utilities (Gnuastro) is an official GNU package consisting of various programs and library functions for the manipulation and analysis of astronomical data. All the programs share the same basic command-line user interface for the comfort of both the users and developers. Gnuastro is written to comply fully with the GNU coding standards so it integrates finely with the GNU/Linux operating system. This also enables astronomers to expect a fully familiar experience in the source code, building, installing and command-line user interaction that they have seen in all the other GNU software that they use.
sites_https_justification: All webpages are hosted by GNU and support HTTPS, this is the top page: https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/index.html
description_good_justification: At the top of the software's main URL (https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/), a short description is given. There is also a list of all the separate programs that the software contains in a link under the top description (it is like GNU Coreutils which builds and installs many programs in one software package).
interact_justification: In the main project webpage (https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/), there are clear titles "Gnuastro mailing lists", "Report a bug", and "Getting involved", with a description under each which contains links for users to easily provide feedback and contribute to the software.
contribution_justification: The main webpage has the necessary top-level links. But the full description on the exact workflow is fully described in "Production workflow" section of the manual (https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/manual/html_node/Production-workflow.html), and there is also a "Forking tutorial" section in the manual (https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/manual/html_node/Forking-tutorial.html) with a fully working series of commands and processes necessary to Gnuastro's Git repository, make changes, commit and push them. Also on how to inform us and how to finally pull their work from the merged repository. As you see there, the importance of working on branches is also thoroughly discussed there. Many first time Git users have used this page so far and have made it more and more easier to use. Generally, there is a full "Developing" chapter in the manual (https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/manual/html_node/Developing.html) which is only devoted to guidelines for the developers
contribution_requirements_justification: The Gnuastro manual has a complete section devoted to "Coding conventions" (https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/manual/html_node/Coding-conventions.html). Generally, there is a full "Developing" chapter in the manual (https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/manual/html_node/Developing.html) which is only devoted to guidelines for the developers
license_location_justification: https://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/gnuastro.git/tree/COPYING
floss_license_justification: Its copyright is GPL-3.0+ (https://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/gnuastro.git/tree/COPYING) The GPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The GPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification:
https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/manual/html_node/index.html#Top

The documentation is also available in many other formats (for example `info' and `man' on the command-line, PDF for print, plain text, and HTML). The documentation in all formats is available here: https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/manual/index.html
documentation_interface_justification:
Gnuastro has both libraries and binaries (programs). In the manual, following the GNU Coding Standards, all programs have a special "Invoking ProgramName" section which gives a few examples commands of how to run the program, followed by the description of options, here are some examples:

https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/manual/html_node/Invoking-astarithmetic.html
https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/manual/html_node/Invoking-astmkcatalog.html

Also, the API for the library functions are also fully described in the manual, you can see the whole list of APIs in different headers in this link: https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/manual/html_node/Gnuastro-library.html . Here is an example: https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/manual/html_node/World-Coordinate-System.html
repo_public_justification: http://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/gnuastro.git
repo_track_justification: All Git repositories do this.
repo_interim_justification: Every commit is given a unique version (based on `git describe'). Before major releases, we release tar-balls in this address: http://alpha.gnu.org/gnu/gnuastro/ . Once this tarball has been sufficiently tested and major bugs fixed do we make an official release. The full versioning of Gnuastro is discussed here: https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/manual/html_node/Version-numbering.html
repo_distributed_justification: Gnuastro is version controlled with Git: http://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/gnuastro.git
version_unique_justification: Gnuastro does have a unique identifier for every commit (based on Git's `describe') and also major releases get a unique tag. For more, please see https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/manual/html_node/Version-numbering.html
version_tags_justification:
Gnuastro uses Git tags for major releases, see under the "Tag" title in this link: http://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/gnuastro.git

The Tag is then used for minor releases, as fully described here: https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/manual/html_node/Version-numbering.html
release_notes_justification:
Every major and alpha release of Gnuastro is announced in the `info-gnuastro' mailing list: http://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/info-gnuastro/

As you can see in each, the announcement comes with a full copy of this release's section in the NEWS file (which is human readable file, even for someone who doesn't know programming or Git). Also, the hashes for the tarballs so users can be sure that what they get is what we distributed.
release_notes_vulns_justification: The NEWS file in each release announcement describes all the important known vulnerabilities (bugs) that have been fixed: http://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/info-gnuastro/
report_process_justification: Any anonymous user can post an issue on our "Support tracker": http://savannah.gnu.org/support/?func=additem&group=gnuastro . They can also send mails to bug-gnuastro:a:t:gnu.org or help-gnuastro:a:t:gnu.org.
report_responses_justification: The full list of solved and unsolved bugs are available in the main project management webpage: http://savannah.gnu.org/bugs/?group=gnuastro
enhancement_responses_justification: All the enhancements and their discussions are listed in our task tracker: http://savannah.gnu.org/task/?group=gnuastro
report_archive_justification: All the development discussions from all our trackers are distributed and archived through the gnuastro-devel mailing list: http://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/gnuastro-devel/
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: There is a "Report a Bug" section in out top webpage: https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/#bug which discusses the process to inform us of any vulnerability.
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: Gnuastro is not a security software. If private issues must be discussed, users are encouraged to contact the maintainer directory (maintainer information is given on main webpage: https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: From the main project management webpage (https://savannah.gnu.org/projects/gnuastro/), it is visible that many bugs (all the important ones) are fixed almost immediately (as of mid May 2017: only 13 open from a total of 59). The rest are minor and will be fixed when the developers have time.
build_justification: Gnuastro uses the GNU Build System (`./configure', `make', `make check', `make install'): https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/manual/html_node/Quick-start.html
build_common_tools_justification: Gnuastro uses the GNU Build System (`./configure', `make', `make check', `make install'): https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/manual/html_node/Quick-start.html
build_floss_tools_justification: Gnuastro uses the GNU Build System (`./configure', `make', `make check', `make install'): https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/manual/html_node/Quick-start.html
test_justification: Gnuastro currently has 51 tests that are executed when the user runs `make check'.
test_most_justification: It covers most of the basic operations, it would be ideal to cover all, but the developers don't have enough resources to invest in them, so we have designed it based on the major features.
test_policy_justification: With every major features, a test is added in the `tests/' directory and thus to `make check'.
tests_documented_added_justification: In the "Developing" chapter of the Gnuastro book, we try to discuss this with the developers or those interested: https://www.gnu.org/software/gnuastro/manual/html_node/Test-scripts.html
warnings_justification: Gnuastro is built with the `-Wall' flag: see AM_INIT_AUTOMAKE in our `configure.ac': http://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/gnuastro.git/tree/configure.ac
warnings_fixed_justification: We fix any compiler warnings that we see or are reported to us to have a clean build.
warnings_strict_justification: That is correct, For example this commit: http://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/gnuastro.git/commit/?id=195fae5be4f3 where several compiler warning were reported to us and we immediately addressed them.
know_secure_design_justification: While the primary developer is an astronomer (not a security expert), Gnuastro has been designed with all the issues in this list in mind and actually applies all of them. Generally, in no time does Gnuastro need special privileges.
know_common_errors_justification: Gnuastro does not deal with these kinds of operations.
static_analysis_justification: We will look into this and try to find a good static code analysis method.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: We haven't implemented a static code analyzer yer.
static_analysis_often_justification: We will implement static code analysis in the future.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: We use Valgrind for checking the dynamic memory allocations in Gnuastro.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: We check every allocation and it is only used if a non-NULL pointer is returned by `malloc' or `calloc'.
general_comments: Gnuastro strives to follow the GNU Coding Standards for high quality code and user interface.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Before each commit is pushed to the main repo a `make distcheck' is done and everything is checked. On major releases, it is tested as part of GNU Guix: http://hydra.gnu.org/job/gnu/master/gnuastro-0.2.x86_64-linux and Debian: https://packages.debian.org/sid/science/gnuastro . We do plan to include automatic continuous integration in the future.
discussion_justification: In Gnuastro, we do all development discussions in Savannah: http://savannah.gnu.org/projects/gnuastro/ . There are separate "Support", "Bug" and "Task" trackers. Each issue receives a special ID from Savannah and is classified by the part of Gnuastro that it relates to. It is possible to select issues based on many criteria. For example, here is the bug tracers: http://savannah.gnu.org/bugs/?group=gnuastro (clicking on "Display criteria" close to the top of the page will allow you to select the bugs by many classes). All discussions in all the trackers is also archived in the Gnuastro-devel mailing list ( http://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/gnuastro-devel/ ).
english_justification: Everything in Gnuastro is currently only in English!
hardened_site_justification: X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
installation_common_justification: Gnuastro uses the standard GNU Build system (`./configure', `make', `make check') which also includes `make install' and `make install'.
build_reproducible_justification: As part of the Debian release, Gnuastro was tested for a reproducible build: https://tests.reproducible-builds.org/debian/rb-pkg/unstable/amd64/gnuastro.html . The two issues reported there have been fixed and in the next release it will be exactly reproducible.

name: A library for exploring persistent homology
description: Aleph is a C++ library for facilitating the integration and implementation of topological data analysis—mostly based on persistent homology—into other applications. It comes with a unit test suit and numerous examples.
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/Submanifold/Aleph/blob/master/LICENSE.md>.
floss_license_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The MIT license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://submanifold.github.io/Aleph/
documentation_interface_justification:
Find the main documentation along with tutorials under: https://submanifold.github.io/Aleph/

It is also possible to generate the reference documentation using `make docs`. No hosting is provided for this documentation so far.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
release_notes_vulns_justification: There are no publicly known vulnerabilities.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: No vulnerabilities have been reported in the last 6 months
test_invocation_justification: CMake with `make test` as a default target
know_secure_design_justification: I am not a security expert, but I try to make Aleph a secure library. Since its main use is scientific research, I doubt that many vulnerabilities are applicable.
know_common_errors_justification: I am not a security expert, but I try to make Aleph a secure library. Since its main use is scientific research, I doubt that many vulnerabilities are applicable.
static_analysis_often_justification: I am adding this to my daily developmental workflow.
dynamic_analysis_justification: Will use American Fuzzy Lop for the parsers. However, since this project is meant for scientific purposes, I doubt that many vulnerabilities are relevant.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Will use American Fuzzy Lop for the parsers. However, since this project is meant for scientific purposes, I doubt that many vulnerabilities are relevant.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.

name: Open vSwitch
contribution_justification: http://docs.openvswitch.org/en/latest/internals/contributing/submitting-patches/
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/blob/master/COPYING>.
floss_license_justification: http://openvswitch.org/charter/charter.pdf The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: Apache-2.0 is an OSI license. The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Extensive manpages and other documentation in the repository and online at http://docs.openvswitch.org/.
documentation_interface_justification: Manpages document OVS-specific details; RFC 7047 and the OpenFlow specification cover more standardized subsets.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: The source repository is updated granularly with features and bug fixes.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: Open vSwitch uses the common x.y.z versioning format.
version_tags_justification: Open vSwitch tags each release with its version number. Tags are signed.
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/blob/master/NEWS>.
report_tracker_justification: A bug tracker is available at https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs-issues.
report_process_justification: A bug tracker is available at https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs-issues though most issues in practice are reported on the mailing lists.
report_responses_justification: Most reported issues include some kind of followup on the mailing list.
enhancement_responses_justification: Most enhancement requests include some kind of followup on the mailing lists.
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: http://docs.openvswitch.org/en/latest/internals/security/ says that reporters may ask for a GPG key while initiating contact with the security team to deliver more sensitive reports.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: http://docs.openvswitch.org/en/latest/internals/security/ says says, "As a basic default policy, we expect report date to disclosure date to be 10 to 15 business days."
build_justification: Open vSwitch uses Autoconf and Automake with GNU make.
build_common_tools_justification: Autoconf, Automake, and GNU make are commonly used.
build_floss_tools_justification: Autoconf, Automake, and GNU make are GNU GPL licensed.
test_justification: Open vSwitch includes an extensive automated testsuite.
test_invocation_justification: The Open vSwitch testsuite is invoked with "make check", which is common for Autoconf-based projects.
test_most_justification: The Open vSwitch testsuite has good coverage, though it does not approach 100%.
test_policy_justification: https://docs.openvswitch.org/en/latest/internals/contributing/submitting-patches/ talks about testing and suggests adding tests as part of contributions.
tests_are_added_justification: The current development branch has 27 more tests than the most recent release (2.7), which has 30 more tests than the release before it (2.6).
tests_documented_added_justification: https://docs.openvswitch.org/en/latest/internals/contributing/submitting-patches/ talks about testing and suggests adding tests as part of contributions.
warnings_justification: Open vSwitch uses GCC and Clang warning options aggressively.
warnings_fixed_justification: Open vSwitch compiles warning free with its default set of warnings on common platforms.
warnings_strict_justification: Open vSwitch compiles warning free with its default set of warnings on common platforms.  Many developers build with "-Werror" to ensure that warnings cause build failures.
crypto_keylength_justification: I believe that OpenSSL as implemented on common platforms meets these requirements.
crypto_working_justification: I believe that OpenSSL as implemented on common platforms meets these requirements.
crypto_pfs_justification: Open vSwitch enables perfect forward security in OpenSSL.
crypto_password_storage_justification: Open vSwitch does not store passwords.
crypto_random_justification: I believe that OpenSSL as implemented on common platforms meets these requirements.
delivery_mitm_justification:
Open vSwitch source code is most commonly delivered through HTTPS or Git-over-SSH.
Open vSwitch does not publish binaries.
delivery_unsigned_justification: Open vSwitch does not use this mechanism.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: I am not aware of any unpatched vulnerabilities of this type.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: Open vSwitch has had one critical vulnerability, which we fixed quickly: https://mail.openvswitch.org/pipermail/ovs-announce/2016-March/000082.html
static_analysis_justification: Developers regularly use "sparse".  Open vSwitch also uses the "Clang" thread-safety analysis and Coverity Scan.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: We fix bugs as they are reported.
static_analysis_often_justification: Many developers run "sparse" on every build.
dynamic_analysis_justification: Developers occasionally use "valgrind" on the testsuite, by running "make check-valgrind".  Some developers use AddressSanitizer.  We also use oss-fuzz.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Developers occasionally use "valgrind" on the testsuite, by running "make check-valgrind".  Some developers use AddressSanitizer.  We also use oss-fuzz.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: Open vSwitch has useful assertions that are always tested.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: We fix bugs as they are reported.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: I believe that OpenSSL as implemented on common platforms meets these requirements.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Open vSwitch uses travis-ci.org to run continuous integration tests.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: The Open vSwitch repository does not contain private credentials.
english_justification: The primary language of the project is English.
crypto_used_network_justification: Open vSwitch supports TLS for network communication.
crypto_certificate_verification_justific: Open vSwitch requires the user to provide SSL certificates and verifies them.
crypto_verification_private_justificatio: Open vSwitch does not use HTTP.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers. X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff". // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
installation_common_justification: Open vSwitch can be installed and uninstalled with "make install" and "make uninstall", or more commonly by using the included Debian and Red Hat packaging.

name: e3-core
description: Core framework for developing portable automated build systems
description_good_justification: Succinct description in the README file and in the wiki at https://github.com/AdaCore/e3-core/wiki
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/AdaCore/e3-core/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
contribution_requirements_justification:
https://github.com/AdaCore/e3-core/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md

We document that we're PEP8 compliant and are asking for verifying it with our checker.
license_location_justification: https://github.com/AdaCore/e3-core/blob/master/COPYING3
floss_license_justification: The GPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The GPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification:
See documentation link on https://github.com/AdaCore/e3-core

https://e3-core.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
documentation_interface_justification: API documentation automatically generated from python source code.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: All commits are available on GitHub.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
release_notes_justification:
https://github.com/AdaCore/e3-core/blob/master/NEWS.md

This file is updated when pushing an official release
build_justification: standard Python projects that can be built and install with python setup.py install. We also provide a way to install and test the software with various versions of Python (tox).
test_invocation_justification: tox and py.test are often used by the Python community
test_policy_justification: No change can be added if it reduces the code coverage.
tests_are_added_justification: Direct push are rejected and we have a pull-request hook in place that rejects any change that reduces the testsuite coverage.
tests_documented_added_justification: Documented in https://github.com/AdaCore/e3-core/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md and automatically verified (code coverage should not decrease)
warnings_fixed_justification: All warnings reported by the linter tools are addressed, when ignored annotation is added to the code source
warnings_strict_justification: All warnings reported by the linter tools are addressed.
know_secure_design_justification: A key developer is also a Security Officer at AdaCore
crypto_floss_justification: Using only basic hash functions and ssl.
crypto_keylength_justification: Security mechanims are use of https (via requests) or smtp (can be configured to use smtplib.SMTP_SSL).
crypto_random_justification: No keys or nonces generated directly by the project.
delivery_mitm_justification: Currently distributed by GitHub using git (ssh or https).
delivery_unsigned_justification:
e3.store will check the cryptographic signature when downloading external sources
In addition the simple store provided as an example allow the use of https
static_analysis_fixed_justification: We cannot push code when a vulnerability is not fixed or explicit flagged as not relevant.
dynamic_analysis_justification: No existing dynamic analysis tool suitable for this project has been identified.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Python is a memory safe language
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: use of assert and manual raise of exception when validating inputs
crypto_weaknesses_justification: We use SHA1 checksum to verify the downloaded content BUT it is possible to configure the download to go through HTTPS. We do not consider the checksum to be a security mechanisms, they are used to detect possible download issues.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Continuous integration results available here: https://github.com/AdaCore/e3-core
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: No code is pushed without a review.
crypto_used_network_justification: Network communications that would be typically used by projects based on e3-core would be implemented using the Python standard library. Our HTTPS wrappers are verifying SSL certificates by default.
crypto_tls12_justification: Provided by the Python standard library.
hardened_site_justification: Based on GitHub.
installation_common_justification:
python setup.py install

pip install / uninstall
dco_justification: Use of a CLA automated through cla-asistant as visible for every pull-request, e.g. https://github.com/AdaCore/e3-core/pull/332
bus_factor_justification:
AdaCore, as a commercial entity, ensures the project will continue with minimal interruption. e3-core is a key component of AdaCore internal infrastructure. See https://github.com/AdaCore/e3-core/network/dependents
See https://snyk.io/advisor/python/e3-core for an analysis of maintainers and contributors.
documentation_architecture_justification:
The project provides a simple API that is documented in https://e3-core.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html
This API is extensible using plugins: https://e3-core.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins.html
documentation_quick_start_justification: An highlight of main API functions is provided: https://e3-core.readthedocs.io/en/latest/quickstart.html
documentation_current_justification: The main documentation is the API documentation that is maintained using Python docstrings and type annotations. The documentation is maintained up-to-date with changes to the code.
documentation_achievements_justification: e3-core uses CII best practices badge https://github.com/AdaCore/e3-core
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: Project site is on GitHub, the Python library is integrated with the Python ecosystem.
internationalization_justification: The project is meant to be used by developers and not end-users.
maintenance_or_update_justification: All backward incompatible changes are documented in https://github.com/AdaCore/e3-core/blob/master/NEWS.md
vulnerability_response_process_justifica: We ask for GitHub issues in https://github.com/AdaCore/e3-core/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
coding_standards_enforced_justification: Enforce at each pull request via tox
build_preserve_debug_justification: We have a Python lib, are are using standard tools
installation_development_quick_justifica: Easy to build and run the testsuite, all documented in CONTRIBUTING.md
interfaces_current_justification: This is met to the best of our knowledge. FLOSS alternatives are regularly reviewed and used when it makes sense.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: Automated via TravisCI and AppVeyor for pull-request. Pushing directly to master without pull-request is disabled.
regression_tests_added50_justification: A test is added after each bug detected.
test_statement_coverage80_justification: Coverage is displayed on the project main page and computed for each pull-request. As documented in CONTRIBUTING.md we're want to be near 100% statement coverage (currently 96%)
test_policy_mandated_justification: We document that "All features or bug fixes must be tested." in contributing.md
input_validation_justification: The only possible untrusted sources would be the external store containing binary files. The tool require that the checksum is stored separately and verify that the download file has the right checksum.
crypto_credential_agility_justification: The project won't read credentials, we rely on external tools, e.g. AWS cli or SSH
signed_releases_justification: We're using Git tag for releases and GitHub is verifying the signature for us.
version_tags_signed_justification: We're using Git tag for releases and GitHub is verifying the signature for us.
small_tasks_justification:
https://github.com/AdaCore/e3-core/issues

The project uses the label "Good first issue" to identify small tasks that can be performed by new or casual contributors.
require_2FA_justification: All changes are pushed using GitHub pull-requests, pushing directly on our repository is prevented. All changes must be approved by AdaCore contributors that have their GitHub accounts configured with 2FA (OTP tokens).
secure_2FA_justification: All changes are pushed using GitHub pull-requests, pushing directly on our repository is prevented. All changes must be approved by AdaCore contributors that have their GitHub accounts configured with 2FA (OTP tokens).
two_person_review_justification: Code review in mandatory on e3-core, no proposed modifications can be merged without a key contributor approval.
test_statement_coverage90_justification: See https://github.com/AdaCore/e3-core codecov badge which currently indicates 93% statement coverage.
test_branch_coverage80_justification: See https://github.com/AdaCore/e3-core codecov badge which currently indicates 93% statement coverage.
security_review_justification: This is a key component of AdaCore's production infrastructure, a security review is performed at least every year.

name: Taking microservices to next level
description: Kikaha aims to be an absurdly fast Java web server designed for microservices. Written over Undertow platform (you know, it is really fast), it was designed to be a micro container that handle high throughput demands and provide high scalability. Its internal design is clean-code-driven, because open source software should be easy to be improved. Also, we believe on the JVM communities, what they have done, the goals we already achieved and on its improvements. This make we proud to contribute to JVM, the fastest web platform ever.
sites_https_justification: The actual documentation is, indeed, hosted on non-HTTPS environment - readme.io. This would change on the next 2.1.x release. Given an http: URL.
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/Skullabs/kikaha/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: http://get.kikaha.io/docs
documentation_interface_justification: The external API is briefly documented through the JavaDoc API, which is the Java standard way to document libraries APIs. Although there is no HTML page with the JavaDoc, using most common IDEs (Intellij IDEA, Eclipse, NetBeans, etc) you are able to retrieve the JavaDoc from the Maven Central. http://search.maven.org/#search|ga|1|kikaha
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
build_floss_tools_justification: It uses maven to build. https://maven.apache.org
test_justification: The software have almost 500 behavior driven tests ensuring the software will not suffer from regression bugs.
test_invocation_justification: Just type `mvn clean test` on the root of the project.
test_most_justification: As the release of 2.1.x version, the software have 75% of its code lines covered.
warnings_justification: It uses the maven and Java defaults to notify developers about language warnings.
warnings_fixed_justification: It has very few warnings (way less than 1 per 100 lines).
warnings_strict_justification: There is a few code generation tasks that emits warnings. Being strict with warnings may turn the project not viable anymore. Despite of this, the software it self have only 2 warnings (as 22 May, 2017).
know_secure_design_justification: The project lead developer is Miere Teixeira which have fixed or closes most of addressed issues: https://github.com/Skullabs/kikaha/issues?q=is%3Aissue+author%3Amiere+is%3Aclosed
know_common_errors_justification: As the leader of the project, Miere is responsible to fix any kind of vulnerability that the software may face.

crypto_pfs_justification: Once the framework itself does not implements any cryptography algorithm, but delegates to third-party implementations. These the third-party implementations address this requirement.
crypto_password_storage_justification: Once the framework itself does not implements any cryptography algorithm, but delegates to third-party implementations. These the third-party implementations address this requirement. BCrypt, by the way, is one its available implementations.
crypto_random_justification: Once the framework itself does not implements any cryptography algorithm, but delegates to third-party implementations. These the third-party implementations address this requirement.
delivery_mitm_justification: Developers can use a SSL certificate to provide HTTPS secure communication between the server and the client.
delivery_unsigned_justification: Developers can use a SSL certificate to provide HTTPS secure communication between the server and the client.

name: FOLIO
description:
FOLIO, an open source project, aims to reimagine library software through a unique collaboration of libraries, developers and vendors. It moves beyond the traditional library management system to a new paradigm, where apps are built on an open platform, providing libraries more choice and delivering new services to users.

The FOLIO platform includes core functionality found in current library management systems and is extensible, allowing libraries to meet ever changing needs.
contribution_justification: https://dev.folio.org/guidelines/contributing/
license_location_justification: We put a LICENSE file at the top of each repository in the FOLIO repo. An example is at: https://github.com/folio-org/okapi/blob/master/LICENSE

version_unique_justification: Modules and APIs use semantic versioning.
discussion_justification: We use GitHub issue and pull request discussions. Our developers are very active on our Slack channel: https://folio-project.slack.com
english_justification: We use Jira for bug tracking and bug reports: https://issues.folio.org. This documentation is in English.

repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.

version_unique_justification: SemVer is mandated by the Symphony Software Foundation (who host this project): <https://symphonyoss.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/FM/pages/62783511/Incubating#Incubating-Releases>.
version_tags_justification: Although the project has yet to release a non-snapshot version, the intent is to use git tags for this.
report_responses_justification: Issue resolution time for the project currently averages 22 hours, as per: <http://isitmaintained.com/project/symphonyoss/clj-symphony>.
enhancement_responses_justification: Issue resolution time for the project currently averages 22 hours, as per: <http://isitmaintained.com/project/symphonyoss/clj-symphony>.
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: All vulnerability reports are expected to be public.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: No vulnerability reports have been submitted yet.
test_justification: The library uses the MIT-licensed "midje" testing suite for Clojure: <https://github.com/marick/Midje>.
test_invocation_justification: The library uses the MIT-licensed "midje" testing suite for Clojure: <https://github.com/symphonyoss/clj-symphony/blob/master/project.clj#L37>.
test_most_justification: Currently the automated test suite  only tests for compilation errors.
warnings_justification: The project team uses the Leiningen "kibit" plugin, which makes suggestions for better alternative forms.
warnings_fixed_justification: Reflection warnings are actively monitored and fixed, via Leiningen's "check" plugin.
warnings_strict_justification: Reflection warnings are actively monitored and fixed, via Leiningen's "check" build tool.
crypto_published_justification: This is provided by the underlying Symphony Java Client library (which is developed independently).
delivery_mitm_justification: Symphony's APIs are only ever accessible via HTTPS, and only then with certificate based auth.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: Vulnerability scanning is one of the services offered by Whitesource: <https://www.whitesourcesoftware.com/>.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: One of the library's transitive dependencies (javassist v3.18.1) has a known vulnerability flagged by Whitesource.  Rather than work around this here, the project team instead elected to upstream to fix it in their dependencies: <https://github.com/symphonyoss/symphony-java-client/issues/65>.
static_analysis_often_justification: Whitesource is run as part of CI: <https://github.com/symphonyoss/clj-symphony/blob/master/.travis.yml#L20>.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Clojure runs on the JVM, which is memory-safe.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: All commits are set to run automatically on TravisCI: <https://github.com/symphonyoss/clj-symphony/blob/master/.travis.yml>.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: Common locations for certificates are explicitly listed in .gitignore file: <https://github.com/symphonyoss/clj-symphony/blob/master/.gitignore>.
english_justification:
Detailed reference documentation is published on GitHub Pages: <https://symphonyoss.github.io/clj-symphony/>.
Bug reports and comments can be submitted in any language via GitHub (although the project team only understands English): <https://github.com/symphonyoss/clj-symphony/issues>.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.

name: 使用nodejs+express+codemirror编写的es6测试平台。可以用来配合阮一峰的教材来学习es
description: 这两天在看阮一峰的《ES6标准入门》，对其中涉及到的代码示例部分，感觉到很不方便，不知道阮老师是如何进行代码调试的。可能是在nodejs环境或者直接在浏览器的控制台中进行调试。我每次都是在nodejs命令行中进行代码编写，由于命令行本身的特点，有一句代码编写错误，都可能导致需要重写所有的代码。由于，我想简单点，开发一个基于web的IDE来运行我们输入的JavaScript或者es2015也就是es6代码。经过一个晚上加一个上午的构思和代码编写，已经完成了基础代码的编写。下图就是这个项目的一个运行示例。利用CodeMirror插件来作为代码编辑插件，并且根据需要，改写了CodeMirror官方的javascript-hint.js文件，使得代码提示的效果更丰富，同时也发现了网上大多数坑人的帖子带来的问题，后面都要有详细的说明。先来简单的看一下我们的系统长什么样吧，至于界面的设计，大家就将就的看一下，毕竟功能才是我们所需要的。

name: Hyperledger Burrow
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/hyperledger/burrow/blob/master/LICENSE.md>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Some documentation basics file contents found.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: We solicit review for pull requests and have a buildable version on the develop branch
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_semver_justification: We use a 'shifted' variant of semver before version 1.0.0, whereby we use the minor number of breaking changes and the patch number for minor changes. This is because we have (rightly or wrongly) built an expectation around the stability/security of a 1.0.0 release. However the tags published on Github do follow semver and meet this requirement.
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/hyperledger/burrow/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md>.
release_notes_vulns_justification: The security bug process is documented in the project's SECURITY.md file: https://github.com/hyperledger/burrow/blob/master/SECURITY.md
report_archive_justification: Project reports are made quarterly to the Hyperledger TSC here: https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/TSC/TSC+Project+Updates
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: Burrow follows this:  https://github.com/hyperledger/burrow/blob/master/SECURITY.md as well as the Hyperledger security team policies: https://wiki.hyperledger.org/display/SEC/Security+Team+Policies
test_justification: Go tests in repo and integration tests in Bosmarmot: http://github.com/monax/bosmarmot
test_policy_justification: Maintainers will not accept feature pull requests without tests
tests_are_added_justification: All recent feature pull requests have tests
know_secure_design_justification: This is rather vague. Insofar as this is a core competency for all developers particularly on platform team then yes.
crypto_pfs_justification: Tendermint uses station-to-station protocol with ephemeral ed25519 keys that provides perfect forward secrecy
crypto_password_storage_justification: We currently allow unprotected local access with the assumption of a secure ambient environment. This is not a good assumption and needs to change.
delivery_mitm_justification: https on github plus checksums on releases
dynamic_analysis_justification: goimports is run, we should add go vet
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Burrow's default build is pure Go - and therefore memory safe. We do have a sqlite build option for Vent. Sqlite3 is well tested in its own right.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: We use ripemd-160 and sha3 for hashing
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardened_site_justification: X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff". // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
